title: How to Be an Expert Rock Band Drum Player

steps.headline: Search for the cheat code to unblock all songs on the internet and apply it.
steps.description: Make sure you have the songs organized by difficulty. You can do this by hitting the pedal until the words "By Difficulty" appear on the top of the screen.

steps.headline: Try the song "Say it Ain't So" by Weezer or "29 Fingers" by The Konks in the easy mode to get used to the drum kit.
steps.description: Play these songs until you get a score higher than 80 percent.

steps.headline: Move on to more difficult songs, for example, "Gimme Shelter" by the Rolling Stones.
steps.description: Play songs on a "difficult level" until you score 80 percent or higher.

steps.headline: Understand the basic rhythm.
steps.description: This includes 3 yellows and red and yellow together, 3 yellows and red and yellow together, and so on, including a pedal hit together with the second yellow hit. This rhythm is the most used; the rest are variations on it. When you learn this, everything else will be easy.

steps.headline: Move on to a more difficult song still on easy mode, for example "Enter Sandman" by Metallica.
steps.description: Play it until you score 80 percent or higher.

steps.headline: Move onto medium mode, and play one song from each difficulty type (solid songs, skilled songs, blistering songs), starting from the easiest to the blistering ones.
steps.description: Don't worry about the impossible songs, they are only a challenge so you won't get bored, but are actually pretty impossible.

steps.headline: Understand the rhythms you play, and the sound the drumsticks make when they hit the pads should sound logical to you.
steps.description: When you're ready, move on to hard mode.

steps.headline: Repeat the process on hard mode, but do two songs of each difficulty type until you score 90 percent or more.
steps.description: You will soon want to move on to expert, but you shouldn't do this until you feel your hands respond without thinking. This normally happens around the 3rd day you've been playing on hard mode. If it doesn't, just keep practicing. Remember that there are some people that have the rhythm already in their heads, and some that need rhythm to be introduced little by little.

text: First Week Search for the cheat code to unblock all songs on the internet and apply it. Make sure you have the songs organized by difficulty. You can do this by hitting the pedal until the words "By Difficulty" appear on the top of the screen. Try the song "Say it Ain't So" by Weezer or "29 Fingers" by The Konks in the easy mode to get used to the drum kit. Play these songs until you get a score higher than 80 percent. Move on to more difficult songs, for example, "Gimme Shelter" by the Rolling Stones. Play songs on a "difficult level" until you score 80 percent or higher. Understand the basic rhythm. This includes 3 yellows and red and yellow together, 3 yellows and red and yellow together, and so on, including a pedal hit together with the second yellow hit. This rhythm is the most used; the rest are variations on it. When you learn this, everything else will be easy. Move on to a more difficult song still on easy mode, for example "Enter Sandman" by Metallica. Play it until you score 80 percent or higher. 2nd week Move onto medium mode, and play one song from each difficulty type (solid songs, skilled songs, blistering songs), starting from the easiest to the blistering ones. Don't worry about the impossible songs, they are only a challenge so you won't get bored, but are actually pretty impossible. Understand the rhythms you play, and the sound the drumsticks make when they hit the pads should sound logical to you. When you're ready, move on to hard mode. Repeat the process on hard mode, but do two songs of each difficulty type until you score 90 percent or more. You will soon want to move on to expert, but you shouldn't do this until you feel your hands respond without thinking. This normally happens around the 3rd day you've been playing on hard mode. If it doesn't, just keep practicing. Remember that there are some people that have the rhythm already in their heads, and some that need rhythm to be introduced little by little.
